name: NPR
text:
Two influential reports suggest that reduced global oil consumption and low prices will continue well into 2021 — if not longer.

"The path forward is treacherous," one advisory body warned.
https://t.co/qAxLbJWKqq

name: NPR
text:
Pennsylvania Gov. Tom Wolf slammed Republicans for celebrating a federal judge's ruling that called some of the state's since-lifted pandemic restrictions unconstitutional.
https://t.co/tbrFuDLfOJ

name: NPR
text:
Senators pressed a Google executive Tuesday over whether the tech giant wields too much power over advertisers and publishers in the digital ad market. It comes amid increasing scrutiny of the company's dominance.
https://t.co/qpUofWOvHR

name: NPR
text:
.@roughly is back with a new season, starting September 16th.  – “School of Scandal” edition. This fall, stories of people shaking things up, sometimes in unconventional ways. It might get dirty, but sometimes that’s just what you gotta do. 
https://t.co/JdhzD9JUM9

name: NPR
text:
Facebook is launching a page focused on climate change facts with "authoritative information about what is happening to our climate, how it's changing," the company's vice president says.
https://t.co/OXkyGADOB4

name: NPR
text:
Most D.C.-area private workers will likely work from home until next summer, according to a survey of hundreds of employers. Many firms cited worries about public transit safety.
https://t.co/ETQmLMtbvE

name: NPR
text:
The Sun has passed into a new 11-year activity cycle — but scientists predict the new cycle's intensity, which will peak in 2025, should be almost identical to the last.
https://t.co/DNVhta491v

name: NPR
text:
60 years ago, a company introduced a computer program that used polling data to predict the impact of political messages. 

At the time, many decried it as a threat to democracy.

But, says historian Jill Lepore, "that's now what our politics has become."
https://t.co/SwGo2ypC5O

name: NPR
text: RT @nprmusic: Ever been through a hard heartbreak? Arlo Parks' (@arloparks) songwriting taps into those familiar (and often uncomfortable) feels. Watch her Tiny Desk (home) concert recorded at home in London. https://t.co/g0AhRPA3Ka

name: NPR
text:
Netflix's CEO argues a creative workplace needs as few policies and rules as possible to thrive — and credits the company's meteoric rise to its unorthodox workplace culture.

Others say it can be ruthless and transparent "to the point of dysfunction." 
https://t.co/DCEJq87rTT

name: NPR
text:
OPEC predicts total oil demand in 2020 will be slashed by nearly 10%.

But that's nowhere near the large-scale pivot away from fossil fuels that scientists say is necessary to fight climate change.
https://t.co/nZzukGafKf

name: NPR
text:
A new book by photographer Janna Ireland showcases the work of Paul R. Williams, the first Black architect in the American West, who believed "good design wasn't just for the rich."
https://t.co/2f6PtXli7z

name: NPR
text:
Forecasters are closely monitoring a pair of weather systems that threaten to deliver more damage in what has already been an active hurricane season. Hurricane Paulette is rolling toward Bermuda while Tropical Storm Sally is moving toward the Gulf Coast.
https://t.co/NZyDfs26y5

name: NPR
text:
A simple DIY project accidentally launched Sandy Chilewich’s 40-year career as a designer, entrepreneur, and creator of the now-famous @chilewich placemat. 

The story is this week’s episode of @HowIBuiltThis with @GuyRaz . Listen now.
https://t.co/2lClUIx7cx

name: NPR
text:
We last spoke with Soumana Saley in 2018. Now he's facing a tough year because of the pandemic. He lost his factory job and craft fairs have gone on hiatus. Despite the hard times, he's committed to sending money to support his school in his native Niger.
https://t.co/QToSQFuUvb

name: NPR
text:
Top Democrats are calling for an investigation after a whistleblower alleged hysterectomies are being performed on immigrants at a detention center in Georgia.

Other accusations include shredding medical requests and refusing to test detainees for COVID.
https://t.co/HSMNpbeTmQ

name: NPR
text:
The vast majority of children dying from COVID-19 in the U.S. are Hispanic, Black and/or Native American, a new CDC report finds.
https://t.co/JXmxF9Vh2y
